info.game_comments: 2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 2, game 18.

(1, 1).clue: To ride the Bluegrass Scenic Railroad, you have to go to this state

(3, 1).clue: Jeans & overalls can be made from this fabric whose name comes from a city in the South of France

(4, 1).clue: 1931:Boris Yeltsin is born in Sverdlovsk, an industrial region in these mountains

(5, 1).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from the FDR Library in Hyde Park, NY.)  In November 1943, while meeting with Churchill & Stalin in Tehran, FDR sketched out his idea for this organization

(6, 1).clue: It's what was showered down upon Charles Lindbergh at a parade in NYC in June 1927

(1, 2).clue: Hop aboard the Green Mountain Flyer for a scenic tour of this state's fall foliage

(3, 2).clue: It sounds like hammerheads provide the material for this, but it's really a worsted fabric for men's suits

(4, 2).clue: 1985:This new General Secretary of the Communist Party brings Yeltsin to Moscow

(5, 2).clue: Good thing Franco was still dead when this man became king

(6, 2).clue: To write down words, especially from audio to written form

(1, 3).clue: The Sugar Cane Train takes folks on a nostalgic steam locomotive trip from Lahaina to Kaanapali on this island

(3, 3).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from Park City, UT.)  Freshly groomed snow that's grooved is called this, for its resemblance to a certain fabric

(4, 3).clue: 1986:Yeltsin is inducted into this national executive & policymaking committee

(5, 3).clue: (Reading Rainbow's LeVar Burton reads the clue.)  We saw  various animal abodes after learning about this type of crab & its search for a new house

(6, 3).clue: In 1998 a $15 million production of this opera was staged in its actual setting, the Forbidden City

(1, 4).clue: Ride in restored 1930s passenger cars on the Oil Creek and Titusville Railroad in this state

(3, 4).clue: This soft fabric originated in Wales; its name comes from the Welsh gwalen ("akin to wool")

(4, 4).clue: 1994:Yeltsin orders Russian troops into this rebellious republic

(5, 4).clue: (Hello, I'm Linda Park. I play Hoshi, the linguistic expert, on Enterprise.)  In Chinese, each symbol represents a word; in Japanese, each symbol a syllable; in Korean, each symbol, this

(6, 4).clue: Middle Caicos is the largest island in this British dependency in the West Indies

(1, 5).clue: Take a trip on the Essex steam train & connect to an optional riverboat cruise in this state

(3, 5).clue: The name of this fabric can precede "steel" & "rose"

(4, 5).clue: 1999:Yeltsin names this 15-year KGB veteran his successor

(5, 5).clue: We're not sure when he sat for this portrait

(6, 5).clue: This general came to power in Panama in 1968 & led the drive to end U.S. control of the canal

(1, 1).clue: This Italian, not Michelangelo, painted the famous "Sistine Madonna" around 1513

(2, 1).clue: Elvis was born on January 8, 1935 in a wood frame house located on Old Saltillo Road in this city

(3, 1).clue: This equine's stripe pattern varies from individual to individual--none is identical to those of another

(4, 1).clue: The first name of this cellist born in 1955 means "friendship"

(6, 1).clue: Seen here, these flowers got their name from the French for "to think"

(1, 2).clue: Before this colony on the Carolina coast was "lost", Sir Francis Drake rescued some of its colonists

(2, 2).clue: Once elected dogcatcher of Tampa, this man, seen here, later contractually received 50% of Elvis' earnings

(3, 2).clue: The Javan species of this ungulate is also known as the lesser one-horned one

(4, 2).clue: At age 13 this violinist from Israel was presented to the U.S. by Ed Sullivan

(5, 2).clue: In Florence (not California):Taddeo Gaddi's "Meeting at" this gate

(6, 2).clue: From the Latin for "earth", it's any of several types of small dogs bred to hunt animals underground in burrows

(1, 3).clue: This magnificent Ottoman's death in Transylvania in 1566 was reportedly kept secret from his troops

(2, 3).clue: Elvis, Johnny Cash, Carl Perkins & Jerry Lee Lewis had an impromptu jam session at this Memphis studio in December of 1956

(3, 3).clue: This beast of burden was domesticated by the Inca about 1,000 B.C.; the Spaniards called it a Peruvian sheep

(4, 3).clue: When this classical guitarist made his formal Paris debut in 1924, the program included a work named for him

(6, 3).clue: Perhaps from the Caribbean taino for "pipe for smoking", it's the dried leaves of a plant of the nightshade family

(1, 4).clue: In 1557 it became a Portuguese outpost, the first European settlement in China

(2, 4).clue: After basic training at Fort Hood, Texas, Elvis shipped out for an 18-month tour of duty in this country

(3, 4).clue: The name of this piglike mammal with a short movable snout is from a Brazilian Indian word meaning "thick"

(6, 4).clue: From Old French for "catch" or "entangle", it's to accuse a serving government official with an offense

(1, 5).clue: This future opera subject ruled Russia from 1584 to 1598, then became czar in his own right

(2, 5).clue: Seen at a 1961 Honolulu press conference, Elvis performed a concert to raise money for this ship's memorial

(3, 5).clue: Unlike the giraffe, which lives in the savannah, this smaller relative lives in the dense jungle

(4, 5).clue: This violinist, seen here, was born in Osaka in 1971

(5, 5).clue: In Washington, D.C.: Vermeer's "Girl with" this color "Hat"

(6, 5).clue: From the Latin for "uplifted", it's to divert energy associated with an unacceptable activity into more acceptable areas

(0, 0).clue: The name of this character, introduced in 1894, is from the Hindi for "bear"
